awd_titl_txt: Developing A Program Model for High School Science Research, Communication and Education Experiences in Living Laboratory
awd_abstract_narration:
As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments. This includes providing multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences, advancing innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments, and developing understandings of deeper learning by participants.  The Museum of Science, Boston (MOS) and Boston University (BU) will conduct a Pilot and Feasibility Study project that leverages the current Living Laboratory (LL) model and expand it to engage high school students (teens) in experimental psychology research, science communication and science education activities. In LL, which is now an extensive network of museums and university researchers across the country, scientists and museum staff collaborate to engage children in studies on the museum floor and educate caregivers about the research. Multi-site implementation and evaluation of LL has also documented positive impacts for undergraduate researchers. Many sites are eager to extend these benefits to high school students by engaging them as practitioners within the model and by providing them with opportunities to engage in current research, education and communication, thereby helping to foster stronger youth identities with science and its applications in society.  

This project expands a ten-year LL partnership between MOS and BU to: 1) pilot a program in which high school students both conduct scientific research and engage the public in learning about science; 2) explore strategies for museums and universities to collaboratively engage, support and mentor high school students in science research, communication and education activities; 3) document curricular, other programmatic, and evaluation materials; and 4) convene professional participants to provide feedback on pilot materials, and assess the viability of implementing similar programs at additional sites. Guided by developmental evaluation, these activities will generate knowledge for the field, and act to increase professional capacity to integrate experiences for teens at multiple LL sites in future projects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

High School is a critical time for fostering youth interest in and affinity for science, as youth explore and come to better understand their own identity and relationship with science. Engaging in authentic practice, feelings of belonging in science communities, and opportunities for mentorship are all known factors in supporting science identity development, particularly for marginalized youth.  Yet, limited opportunities exist for high school students to engage in science research and public science communication activities, or receive mentorship from members of science communities in these aspects of science practice. Museums are ideal places for youth to explore their relationship with science, offering a wide variety of content across disciplines, delivered in multiple modes. This project tested a program that engages high school students in science research within the Living Laboratory model, which pairs academic researchers and informal science learning professionals to conduct studies with museum visitors and educate families about science research involving human subjects. 

As tested and refined through this project, the Teen Science Research, Communication and Education Program (TSRCP) is a year-long experience in which high school students: 1) engage in research practices, 2) engage in science communication practices, 3) engage in science education practices, 4) experience mentorship from STEM (science, technology, engineering, math) professionals, and 5) become members of scientific communities. Evaluation of TSRCP across two cohorts of youth found that:

  • Teens developed greater confidence in their research skills (particularly for data collection), science communication skills, and education skills, and refined their understanding of their own science knowledge, as well as gaps in their own knowledge;
  • Immersing youth participants in the work of two science organizations (a museum and a university), was an effective strategy for supporting teens? sense of community and belonging in science communities, which teens attributed to regularly interacting with colleagues and actively contributing to projects for both institutions; 
  • Case studies provided a detailed and nuanced understanding of changes in teens? science identity through participating in the program, which were subtle in the aggregate analysis but appeared to be meaningful for each individual; and
  • Teens refined their understanding of their interest in and affinity for specific aspects of science through the program, developing a more nuanced understanding of their own identity and relationship with science practice and science communities.

 

Broader Impact

This project built evidence-based knowledge about trajectories of science identity for youth participants and how to support those trajectories; and offered new insights about, and tools for measuring, science identities to the field of informal science learning. Products of these knowledge building efforts include two formal reports documenting the evaluation methods and outcomes for youth who participated in the pilot cohorts, as well as a manuscript on involving youth in research activities.  The project also impacted the field of experimental psychology through teens contributing to novel research related to children's economic beliefs and decisions related to equity, as well as the role of structural mindsets (e.g., fixed vs. growth) in motivation. In addition, the project generated knowledge about interdisciplinary collaboration across the fields of experimental psychology, informal science learning, science education, and science communication, all fields that have a stake in broadening participation in STEM, and built capacity for partnership among museum professionals and academic researchers by providing tools to engage high school students in authentic STEM experiences.

A major product of the project was a free Resource Toolkit to support museum and academic professionals in implementing activities that build youth research, communication, and education skills. The toolkit is free and available to download from the project's landing page:  https://www.informalscience.org/developing-program-model-high-school-science-research-communication-and-education-experiences. The work that youth did with mentors during the project also led to novel research products (including a study pre-registration, academic posters, conference presentations, and drafts for sections of manuscripts), novel educational products (including online exhibits about artificial intelligence and animal skull anatomy) and novel science communication products (including caregiver handouts that describe the methods of experimental psychology studies conducted by youth researchers, as well as poster presentations about research findings aimed informal science learning professionals).


Last Modified: 03/31/2023
Modified by: Rebecca E Kipling
